div.head: /. SAD DEATH OF JUDGE KEILLT
div.p: Wo regret to announce the 4*atb, undr painful circumstances, of Judge Keilly, Iat 111 American judge in tho Mixed Court of Appea who had resided in Egypt for-twenty yean The accideiit by which he met his dooth, i 06 thus reported in the “New York Horald (Paris) of January 29 :—A- well-dressed mai *s ap|ioariug to bo about Sixty years of age, we knocked down by a delivery van on the Plac do la Concorde yesterday.' Ilo nas taken to th ?•' Beaujon Hospital, whore ho died in the ever I ng. In his pocketbook was found a card wit or tho address, “Judge Keily, 49, Dorerestcee *1 Piccadilly, London." Tho late judge was appointed to the Corn • •f 1st Iustauoe at Cairo in- the Khediviato < r0 Tewfik l’odia and was promoted to th* .Qoui 3 3 ol Appeal some years altcrwarda. BothTteJad eh |1M wife had a Urge circle of friends iuijgnr •h |ur thoy were most genial Aid hospital^ ™. Ju.lgo Keilly loaves two aoua and a’ daughty c*3 l'ho Utter is married to Captain Hall, of th Irish Rides.

hip A Dementi.—Mr. Aquiline, manager of the rr.y Tcwtik PoUce Hotel at Helouan, writes to us on the subject ol the incorrect statement made m a Cairo uioiuiug newspaper to the effect th.- .hat be has been appointed manager of tbe ol .National Hotel at Cairo, lio writes : “I shad tool obliged it you will moke it public Unit u. circuwsuuices causeu mo to ilochue the kind oiler mode to mo to work the abovo hotel." The Cretan AIukdek.—Tho enquiry into llje the circumstances mtoudiug tbe murder ol a Cretan lawyer, Zagaki, by the Cretau poet auu ,l,.e patriot, Meuegakis, negau ibis morning at tho ileileuic consular Court at Alexandria. Tbe ,llu tiogeiiy look place bore a low months ago but rl° mo nationality ol tbe assassin was unsettle■ uutii tbe last lew days. Mencgakis has made a complete coulossiou of bis crime, which ap- pears to have been of a purely political charac- ter, the victim having, It is alleged, betrayed the cause ol the isuvuduni to the Button iu the .ate resurrection.

Tbe Khedive will hold the Konrban Beyram reception at Abdeen Palace on Tuesday next, 11th mat. The order of the reception .will be published in our issuo ol Saturday next. div.head: GERMAN VICTORY IN STAMUOL'L.
TILE PKoJbCIED NEW LOAN.
div.p: Consta.n riNOPLK, February 8. The remarkable stiugg.e betweeu tbo German and French Embassies here, with the object ol inducing tbe Porte to ux|>cnd a considerable proportion of tlio projected uow loan ol £5,000,1X10 from tbu Imperial Ottoman Bank upon guns in ilieir ro-pective Countries, enden iu a victory for Germany. Tbe Porte consented to buy Krupp guns. M. Constant, French Am- bassador here, therenp-.n m.tilied tbe Porto that the Paris market wuuld be closed against the now loan. The Ottoman Bank consequently withdrew from -the whole transaction. The Deutsch Bank is now oUcring to assist the Treasury. (Hotter.

div.head: GERMANY AND ENGLAND.
MR. LEES SPEECH.
div.p: London, February 8. Mr. Lee, speaking again at Eastleigh, referred to the extra rdiuary outcry which had been raised over his last >q>eecli. ‘Hie latter wan a plain recital of certain naval reforms, but a meaning had been read into it that never existed. Ho bad suggested no threat to whioh any foreign Power could take exception. (/<•)' Amongst the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice Sir Beujamin Baker, Sir John Aird, Mr. Franz Bayer, Mr. and Mrs. V. Heller, Lt. Col. Mortou Duckelt, Mr. John Smith, Mr. G. F. aud Mina Binl, Mr. and Mrs. N. P. Cairties, Mr. Beruheim aud Ihtuily, Mrs. and Miss Clayton.

PLAGUE AT LIVERPOOL.
div.p: Liverpool, February 8. A fatal case of plague lias occurred here ‘-n board the dS. “Crewe Hall" from Rangoon. l NOTES FUOM 8UEZ. “ (FbOH .2CH P^tMPOroiXT). J- MARQUIS DI RUDINI’S VISIT. ». 8uex, Fobruary 8. is The Marquis di Rudini, ex-Prime Minister of l" Italy, arrived at 8uet this afternoon by the n, 4 20 train from Cairo on route torMaaaowah. is At the station be was met by Mr. Luigi Do- jo perais, Italian Vice-Consul at 8uez, Mr. Aug. ie Pacho, and other members of the Italian n- o»mmunity. Shortly afterwards, the Plorio- [L Rubattino steam-launch conveyod tho Marquis it, on board the steamer “ Tobe, " which sailed in the evening lor Masaowah.
div.head: of % COLLISION INTHE CANAL
div.p: rt . The British steamer " Goorkha " collided in [j the Canal last Sunday afternoon, near Shaluf it, slnfiou, with tho S^. "Solo,” which was moored f._ at the time. Both steamers sustained some J damage over the water line.
div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
BANKING IN EGYPT.
div.p: Tbe Comptoir National d’Escompte de Paris expocts to have its Alexandria branch opened lor working by next June. The Bank of Rome’s new branch at Alex- andria will open here in about two months’ time. Tbo Credito Itariauo is considering the advisability ul o-Uaulubiug a branch bore, but nas come to no dobuite decision on the matter aa yet. Tbe now Geruian-Greek-Orient Bank will establish brauenes ib Egypt, but nut im- mediately, as it will start operations Erst at Athens mid Constantinople.

Our Constantinople Correspondent sends us Uie luilowiug details on this new Levantine uauk :—lu Greece Uie orauebes ot tbe NaUon- al Uauk will be at too disposal ol the Orieut Rank, so it will not be necessary to open new uianches iu that country. But in pruporUou with tne development ot business, Uie Orient uauk win establish branches in various towns ot Turkey, Egypt, aud other countries in the East. Willi regard to Uie capital, the National uauk lur Deutschland, ol uerlin, aud the Na- tional Rouk of Greece haro taken all the siiarcs, the value uf winch is 10 million francs. I bey have reserved to themselves the right to make a public issue within three years. M. A nting, mauager ul tbe National Bank lur Deutscbiaud aud one ot those interested in the Orieut Bank, has stared, iu an interview, mat the aim of tbe now tinaucial establish- ment is to Lieu i tale the importation of Hellenic products into Geruiauy. It will advauco uiouey on bibs of lading. M. Wituiig also said that the Orieut Rank would establish iu Ureece storehouses lor wares which the proprietor does uot wish' to export immediately and on which the Orient Rank will also advance money. The Bank will endeavour to oome to an understanding with the Deutsche-Levan to Lmio to iacihtate the export trade.
div.head: WIRELESS TELEGRAPHY AT SUEZ.
div.p: It is expected that Lloyd's wireless telegraphy station at Port Tewfik will be completed by the end of March, when Suez will be in communica- tion with steamers in the -Rad Sow h*n»0 wireless* Apparatus on board, as well u with Port 8aid.
div.head: ‘ PILGRIM 8TEAMSK ASHORE
div.p: The Greek steamer “Kilikia," bound to Jeddah with a large number of Turkish pilgrims on board, grounded iu the Canal in the Small Bitter Lako, aud was refloated yesterday with the assistanne of a Canal Company’s tug. The “ Kilikia." sustained no damage whatever, and prooeeded on her journey.
div.head: THB LAST OP THB PILGRIM8.
div.p: Tho Khedivial Mail Line, with a view to clearing ont tho remaining foreign pilgrims at Suez, who haduotthe means to pruoeed on their journey, senttheirS.8. “Menzalah" to Suez. The vessel Bailed for Jeddah yesterday afternoon, after taking on board 600 pilgrims at a very low rate, and 300, who were not in a position to pay, were carried absolutely free. These are tho last pilgrims this year on their way to the Holy City viASuez.
div.head: “FEDOBA” AT THE ABBAS
SIGNA. BBLLINCIONI’8 SECOND APPEARANCE.
div.p: The performance of Ftdora at the Abbas Helmy Theatre yesterday evening, with Signa. Bellincioni in the title rOle, was undoubtedly an event in the local theatrioal world. A more finished performance it would be im- possible to imsgine on any stage, and the result was a repetition of the great artiste’s triumph of Saturday last Fedora is as exceed- ing interesting opera, in that the orchestral treatment is very distinct from that acoepted in most works of the kind : it has a curious reminisoonoe of Wagner, notably of Trittan, in oertain parts. Tbe libretto, known to most people through M. V. 8ardou, is certainly calculated to furnish good dnmatio singing, and no artiste is better fitted to bring ont to the full the dramatio points with which it abounds than Signora Bellincioni. Her performance was one of tho most remarkable achievements in the art of musio-drema that we have ever witnessed. 8he knew bow to work towards a climax, both in particular and in general, when the first of all realised the imprisonment of tie great depths of her passion, and wbon she later realised the ripeness and fulness of her ultimate despair. She was, in a word, magnificent; and her every action betrayed the consummate actress that she is. Tbe womanly love and devotion to the husband who is slain, her cunning in oompaasing her terrible revenge, her passion for her lover, are depioted with masterly skill and daring fidelity. With what exqui«ite gentleness and feeling she wins the affection of her lover; with what overpowering force and majesty she faces and vanquishes the murderer of her husband! Tbe infinite pathos of the concluding act, the pathetic picture of the desperate woman who flies to poison as a relief from her mental agony, with the face of a Madonna, and the great, sad eyes full of a sorrow for whioh thore can be no alleviation are, in truth, things that no one who has witnessed them will ever forget Fedora is a character that exactly suits the tomperamont, the personality, and the splendid taleqt of the great Italian actress and singer. Sbo was well seoonded in her trying rflle by Sig. Pagani aa Conte Loris, as well as by the other performers. 8ig. Pagani is a tenor with a future and shared in Signora Bellincioni's great triumph. He sang with taste aud no little dramatio power, although at times he seemed rather nervous, which was probably due to the prosenoe and personality of Siguora Bellincioni. The orchestra did full justioe to the beautiful music of the opera, and tbo ohorus worked well. Tho staging ol the opera left nothing to be desired, both the scenery and costumes being exoelleat. Signora Bollincioni's dresses were nothing less than superb.
div.head: DEVELOPMENT OF FARSHUT.
div.p: Our Farshut Correspondent states that the Postmaster-General has decided to open a branch of the postoffice savings bank at Farshut in consequence of the petition ot the inhabitants, whioh be voioed in our columns. The inhabitants are delighted with Saba Pasha’s promptness in hearkening to their wishes. The employes of tbe Corporation of Western Egypt are still hoping that the Railway Administration will grant their request and stop the “train de luxe'"at Farshut station.
div.head: HELOUAN RAILWAY.
div.p: Since the Dolta Light Railway Company has taken over the Cairo-Helouan lino, great satisfaction has boen evinced at tbo reforms that tbe company has introduoed. We extract the following passage from our vernacular ouutemporary "Misr”: Wo are requested by several peoplo inhabit- ing Helouan to express their warmest thanks for the many aud various reforms brought about by tbe Delta Company on the lino which before long they oxpect to become one of the most orderly and the least dangerous of lines. Tbo reason that some are conducting a virulent campaign against the company, despite its recent existence, is due to the mere bet that they are uot willing to squander money in the samo way as the former oompany with the view to preventing hypocrites from exhibiting their crying and manifold defeats. Tho object of tbe now oompany is reforms in the full sense of the word, and no babbling or nonsense whatever on tbe part of ill-intentioned people is to deter thorn from attaining this moat commendable object.
div.head: EGYPTIAN CIGARETTES.
div.p: Tbe export of Egyptian cigarettes during tbe past year has greatly increased. In 1903 tbe total export of cigarettes from this oouutry amounted to 531,199 kilos, of the value of LE. 423,332. During 1904 the amount exported was 620,476 kilos, ol the value of LB. 494,964, au increase ou the previous year of 89,277 kilos aud L.E.71,632. The export to Knglaud last year amounted to LE. 79,478, as agaiust LB. 78,208 in 1903. The principal figures lor the other countries were as follows: Germany, LB. 247,236, as agaiust LE. 195,010 iu 1903, Aus- tria, LE.38,101, as against LE.26,875 in 1903 PranoeLB. 8,797, as against LE. 13,166 in 1903. China and tbe For East, LE. 18,221 aa against LE. 12,555 in 1903, British Possessions in the Far East, LK. 57,693 as against LE 65.558 in 1903, Swedeu.LB. 10,743 as against Ck 11,107 in 1903, Switzerland, LE. 6,891 as against 6,620 in 1903, Belgium, LE 9,182 as against 8,115 in 1903.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENT
div.p: Tbe EE “Perim," of the Westoott and I au ranee Line, left Malta yesterday and is j due here on Sunday with a general oargo from ^ London. The Ellennan 8iJ. "Avon" sailed henoe yee- p.fc terday afternoon direct for Liverpool, with general cargo, including 2,635 bales of ootton. - The Moss liner “Ramoses" sailed yesterday morning from Malta and is due boro on 8etor- y r day afternoon, with passengers, mails, and ^ general cargo. • „ .Mr The 8.S. “Britannia,” of tho Papayanm M • line, left Liverpool yesterday afternoon and is yr oxpected to arrivo, with mails and passengers, yf on or about the 26th inst, . pol cotptian lam sunr.

(From our Financial Corxwomddtt.) London, February 8. The present week has been characterised by cheerfulness in oar Stock Markets, owing in a great measure io the growing belief that Russia cannot much longer continue the war, and also to tho hope that the Tsar ia beginning to Have hjs own way in reierenoe to the reforms. Ibo Faria and Berlin financiers have been making the moat of the amelioration- of the trouble in 8t Petersburg and have hoisted up the prioe of Russian Four* to over 20 again. Ot stock* and share* then ia little to report this week of interest, to your readen. Am far as the mining section is oonoeroed, business in South Africans nosms to be at a coesplete standstill at promt, with a drooping tendency in price*. Egyptian mining properties, unlike the other Egyptian companies, are not yet independent and are still under tbe wing of the South African Market, and consequently they suffer wiih Kaffirs when the Utter are weak. Nile Valley, have dropped to 2.1/lti at the present moment, a prioe whieb may tempt speculative investors,, AM forgetting that the oompany is to a Urge extent in the hands of ‘^»--r ~r ly acquired a large and United Africans at 1.9/16 shoeid be worth attention. It is evident that the market anticipate an motive future; for a special book of referenoe has just been published, “The Egypt and Sudan Mining Handbook.” Other Egyptian stocks are steady and hold their prtoes well generally. Bonk shares are a strong point, especially National Banks, whioh are in tmmand at 26 in anticipation of th* dividend. The market expects a distribution of 15s. per share. Some aay under, but 15a. is the general idea. Agricultural* are firm at 10 7/8, other pnoee are steady with little or no change on Uie week, except %yptian Markets, whioh nave fallen bock to 1. All Paris stoeka hare been wonderfully well supported, especially Russians, which they manage to keep np to the level of 90;it ie really wouderinl how little of this stock oomes out at this prioe, for it certainly should tempt holders. Japanese stocks keep strong. Money is cheap and the investment market is strong, though not an actire ope, and Consols keep finn at 88}.
div.head: MISS HOESLI’8 CONCERT.
div.p: Miss Hoesli’s conoert at the New Khedivial Total last night was a great success. There vas a large audience in spite of the bad veather. The talonted Swiss lady was assisted >y the distinguished amateurs, Messra. Fos- jolo, Jaoot des Combes, Weedon, and Ehrlich, rbe concert began with Handel's well-known Largo in G Major, sung by Mias Hoesli, assist- by Mr. Ehrlich at the piano and Mr. Weedon arith the violin. Mias Hoeali's voioe was beautifully modulated to suit this diffioult piece. It was much applauded by a critical sudieuoe. M. Fasoolo followed with a violin duet by Sinving, in whioh be was assisted by a friend, whose name was not on the programme. This intricate pieoe was executed with marvellous facility. Tbe sooompaniment wss cleverly given by Mrs. Foeoolo. Three romances were next sung by Miss Hoesli, An Die Nsoht (Bohm), Chant Hindoo (Bembcrg), and Liebesleier (Weingartner).. The last item was especially appreciated and was given with great depth of feeling and perfect harmony. Beethoven’s Adagio was well given by Messrs. Weedon, Des Combes, and Bhrlioh, followed by two solos by Mr. Fusoolo. Sohubert's L'Abeillo was exoellently played and had to be given again to satisfy the demands for an enoore. Mias Hoesli then sang Xavier Le- ronx's Lo Nil, accompanied by M. Dee Combes on tbo 'cello and Mr. Ehrlich on the piano. Tho 'cello adapted itself very well to Miss Hoesli’s powerful voioe. Tho oonoert, which closed with three romances sung by Miss Hoesli, again showed the variety of that lady’s talents, and the bouquets and applause she received showed bow muoh her splendid vocal gifts are appreciated by tho connoisseurs of Alexandria.
